ul.li: 2010-12-13 Sequence diagrams are an area that lots of students find difficult. I have extended the "sequence diagram handout" material (see last section "important points" of the handout below).
2010-12-16 Worksheet 2 has been marked and returned to students in surgeries and today's lecture. Students asked questions about the marking and the various questions and the model answer.
2010-12-16 I have released the model answers for worksheet 2 (see below).
2010-12-17 I have released the marks for the CO2006 week 10 lab test on JUnit. The marks were emailed. More detailed feedback is available on printed scripts from the convenor.
2011-01-18 I have posted the solution for the CO2006 week 10 lab test, see below.

Week 4 lab test was a multiple choice Java quiz conducted electronically. Students had access to the internet, the course textbook (Java Precisely) and any notes they wanted to bring to the lab. Individual feedback is available from the e-learning website. The class average was 60%. The feedback form is here.
Week 10 JUnit lab test here and solutions here. The feedback form is here.

Java.
The book Java Precisely is recommended. A pdf which should be printed duplex is here
There is some good material on the local Java Crash Course page here
There is a good set of Java exercises here. If you are weak in Java, try and do these exercises. Some solutions are here.
Dia. There is a dia tutorial here.
Week 3 Java programming
Week 4 lab test

Week 5 Class and object diagrams
Class and object diagrams will be taught in lectures.
Lab: Recall the "Porkpie library" case study from the week 4 surgery (see below; you should also look at the model answer). Try and draw an analysis class diagram using ***dia***. For the main use cases, what methods do the classes need to have? What attributes? What are the associations between classes? Some points:
Just because there is a line from Public to JoinLibrary (membership) to Staff in the use case, doesn't mean there is a static association between the classes. Use cases represent dynamic processes; class diagrams represent static associations.
Methods that are called by a class do not necessarily go on that class (in fact, they rarely do) eg borrowBook is called by a LibraryUser, but that doesn't mean LibraryUser should have a method borrowBook.
If a libraryMember and a staffMember are involved in borrowBook, it does not mean that the method borrowBook should be on either of these two classes. People involved in use cases do not determine where the associated method goes. This is the same point as above.
Everybody has access to the "LibrarySystem" (typically a class called "Library"); don't complicate your class diagrams by drawing lines from each class to class Library: just add a note saying that the Library instance is global.
Lab solution is here
Week 6 class and sequence diagrams here
Week 8 activity diagrams here
Week 9 basic JUnit here
Week 4: Surgery_1.pdf Surgery_1-Model_Answer.pdf
Week 9: implementation_class_diagrams.png
Instructions are here

Week 5 Class and object diagrams
Class and object diagrams will be taught in lectures.
Lab: Recall the "Porkpie library" case study from the week 4 surgery (see below; you should also look at the model answer). Try and draw an analysis class diagram using ***dia***. For the main use cases, what methods do the classes need to have? What attributes? What are the associations between classes? Some points:
Just because there is a line from Public to JoinLibrary (membership) to Staff in the use case, doesn't mean there is a static association between the classes. Use cases represent dynamic processes; class diagrams represent static associations.
Methods that are called by a class do not necessarily go on that class (in fact, they rarely do) eg borrowBook is called by a LibraryUser, but that doesn't mean LibraryUser should have a method borrowBook.
If a libraryMember and a staffMember are involved in borrowBook, it does not mean that the method borrowBook should be on either of these two classes. People involved in use cases do not determine where the associated method goes. This is the same point as above.
Everybody has access to the "LibrarySystem" (typically a class called "Library"); don't complicate your class diagrams by drawing lines from each class to class Library: just add a note saying that the Library instance is global.

Java.

Week 3 Java programming
Week 4 lab test

Week 5 Class and object diagrams
Class and object diagrams will be taught in lectures.
Lab: Recall the "Porkpie library" case study from the week 4 surgery (see below; you should also look at the model answer). Try and draw an analysis class diagram using ***dia***. For the main use cases, what methods do the classes need to have? What attributes? What are the associations between classes? Some points:
Just because there is a line from Public to JoinLibrary (membership) to Staff in the use case, doesn't mean there is a static association between the classes. Use cases represent dynamic processes; class diagrams represent static associations.
Methods that are called by a class do not necessarily go on that class (in fact, they rarely do) eg borrowBook is called by a LibraryUser, but that doesn't mean LibraryUser should have a method borrowBook.
If a libraryMember and a staffMember are involved in borrowBook, it does not mean that the method borrowBook should be on either of these two classes. People involved in use cases do not determine where the associated method goes. This is the same point as above.
Everybody has access to the "LibrarySystem" (typically a class called "Library"); don't complicate your class diagrams by drawing lines from each class to class Library: just add a note saying that the Library instance is global.
Lab solution is here

Week 8 activity diagrams here

Just because there is a line from Public to JoinLibrary (membership) to Staff in the use case, doesn't mean there is a static association between the classes. Use cases represent dynamic processes; class diagrams represent static associations.
